Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. DR. GRIFFITH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: An online chat is in progress with the Surgeon General.

Dialogues.Line: JerseyGirl wants to know if marijuana can make you sterile.
Is this JerseyGirl asking the question, or JerseyBoyfriend?
Both.

Okay. Well, there's no evidence so far that marijuana has a permanent effect on the male or female reproductive systems. A few studies have suggested that heavy marijuana use may have an effect on male testicular function, but that effect would be reversible. So, if JerseyBoyfriend is concerned then he should mention it to his doctor.
Pixelad wants to know if marijuana can cause cancer.

No conclusive study to date has shown that it does. However... and this is a big however... cellular, genetic and human studies all suggest that the smoke from pot is a risk factor in acquiring respiratory disease. So, if Pixelad wants to be able to walk up a flight of stairs without throwing up, he should put the bong back in the closet behind the Allman Brothers albums where it belongs.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Josh! [to herself] What the hell kind of name is Pixelad? [loudly] Josh!
I'm done?
Yeah.
Efficiency, Donna.
Yeah.
Efficiency and professionalism, and we're out of here at nine o'clock on a Wednesday night.
Doesn't hurt the President's in Tokyo.
Yeah, well, there does seem to be a little less work to do when he's in a different hemisphere, but nonetheless...
Efficiency and professionalism.
With a healthly dollop of leadership skills... the well-placed, well-worded memo. Nobody goes off the reservation, everybody does their job. Turn off your computer. Let's go.
No, I'm going to stay and watch this. I think maybe you should too.
What is it?
The Surgeon General's doing an online chat.
What's she talking about?
Decriminalizing marijuana.
See you tomorrow. Josh exits. Pause. Josh comes back.
What's she talking about?
[reading] "Do you favor the decriminalization of marijuana?"
[reading] "That's not for me to say. I can tell you that marijuana poses no greater public health risk than nicotine or alcohol..."
[reading] "...and doesn't share the same addictive properties of heroin and LSD."
[reading] "Yet, bizarrely, to many of us in the health care profession, the law categorizes it as a Schedule I narcotic while putting a government seal on a pack of cigarettes."
Yeah, somebody didn't get your memo.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Yeah.
[walks in] I need you to take a look at this.
What is it?
It's a transcript of an online chat Millicent Griffith just did, page 8. Donna walks in.
Toby's headed to his office and Sam's on the phone.
I can't talk to him right now.
He says it's important.
I'm gonna be there in a minute. [Donna exits.]
[reading] "The Allman brothers?
It gets a lot worse. [paces with his hand on his forehead]
"Marijuana poses no greater public health risk than nicotine or alcohol doesn't show the same addictive properties as bizzarely categorized as..." and I quit!
Let's go. They walk out of her office.
Is she kidding me with this?
Nope.
When did it happen?
She finished five minutes ago. Talk me through the next twelve hours.
These people got a story. I guarantee you they called AP already... Carol, get me the wires!
[passing by] Yeah.

It's too late for the Times and the Post, but LA and San Francisco will have it. It will be above the fold, the Today show will lead with it, Russert's gonna do a segment. Josh spots Toby walking towards them.
Toby!
Guys, I'm in the Blue Ribbon meeting, I got labor yelling at me, I got a real situation developing over there.
Yeah, but there's a bit of a situation developing here too.
What's going on?
Read that.
Page 8. [to Josh] Why didn't you call me?
While it was happening?
Yes!
So you cold do what?
When did it happen?
She finished about five or ten minutes ago.
You saw it happen?
Yeah.
Why didn't you get me?
What were you going to do? Sam approaches them. They're all standing in the bullpen with large clocks showing world time above their heads.
End the interview!
How?
By ending it!
Listen, something's happened.
We know.
How do you know?
Josh was watching in real time.
I'm not gonna belay into the computer screen, Toby.
What are you talking about?
The Surgeon General, what are you talking about?
Never mind. What did Griffith do?
She reversed our position on marijuana.
All right. First things first what time is it in Tokyo?
They're fourteen hours ahead.
I thought it was thirteen.
Eastern daylight.
So it's fourteen hours ahead.
Yes.
Are we sure it's ahead, and not beind?
Guys, there are clocks on the wall. Everyone but Sam looks at the clocks.
Okay, so it's almost 11 o'clock in Tokyo.
Yeah.
Ginger!
Yeah.
Get Larry and Ed.
And anybody else in my office.
We'll be in the Roosevelt Room. They walk to the Roosevelt Room, Sam following behind reading the transcript.
I'm sorry... 11 in the morning, 11 in the afternoon?
It's 11 A.M.
The Allman Brothers?
Keep reading.
So if it's not a story until tomorrow morning then they're not gonna have it until tomorrow night. We bought it!
We bought two days.
How?
Plane ride.
When does he leave?
Seven P.M. Thursday.
Tomorrow?
Yes.
Local time?
Which local - theirs or ours?
It will be 7 P.M. Thursday in Japan when he leaves.
And he lands here when? Everyone gives each other an annoyed look.
Okay, the flight is 13 hours long.
[covers her face] This isn't happening.
He's going to travel Easward from Tokyo, leaving at seven pm, so when he crosses the international dateline
He will have traveled back in time to what?
Three A.M.
Which puts him down in Washington at P.M. Thursday.
He's gonna land in Washington an hour before he took off?
Yeah.
And that's not a story that beats the Surgeon General? Donna walks in.
Toby, they're calling for you over there.
[getting up] I'm gonna go get yelled at some more. Josh, you need to get Leo.
Call Tokyo.
Yeah. [to C.J.] Carol's got the wires.
Thanks. [runs out]
This clock should be in military time.
Yeah, 'cause that's less confusing.
The man's gone a hundred and fifty hours. How can it be Thursday the whole time?
Listen. Japan is nine hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time...
Don't.
[on the phone in the back] Sophie, this is Donna Moss. Could you locate the Chief of Staff for me please?
What were you talking about before?

I've just been told by someone I believe that a full-page ad had been taken out by the Family Values Leadership Concil that is going to appear in 22 newspapers tomorrow. It lists many prominent people and it congratulates them for denouncing the movie Prince of New York.
What's the problem?
The President is one of the prominent people they congratulate.
The President denounced the movie?
No!
Then how can they run that ad?
I have no idea. But I don't like who we're being congratulated by.
[hands Josh the handset] Josh.
Yeah. [takes the phone] Yeah, Leo, we got a couple of problems here.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY
CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam sees a rubber ball hit his glass window. He walks over to Toby's office, who continues throwing the ball.

Dialogues.Line: I'm here.
Thanks.
We're doing this again?
[puts on a baseball cap] Yeah.
'Cause I just got you off that little bellman's thing.
[takes the cap off] Here's my problem. Sam sits down.
The AARP wants the President to put Seth Gillette on the Commission, so does the AFL-CO, it's important to them and for that reason I think it's got to be important to us.
There's another good reason.
It neutralizes him.
He can't attack the Commission if he's on it.
Which is why if we ask he'll say no.
Maybe, maybe not.

Yeah, but we can't risk that. First of all, we need him on the Commission, or else labor and seniors will be suspicious from the getgo; second, if he's not going to be on the Commission, it can't be because he turned us down.
So either we get him on the Commission, or if we don't, we make sure it's because we never asked him.
Yeah.
[walks in] Sam? He's on the phone.
Thanks. [to Toby] Yeah, I don't know the answer to that.
Okay, well. Thanks for stopping by.
Yeah. As Sam picks up the phone in his office, Toby throws the ball at him again. The ball bounces off the glass but Sam doesn't so much as flinch.
Charlie!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Charlie is sitting in a chair with a book.

Dialogues.Line: Moshimoshi. Konichiwa, Sam. Ikaga dess ka.
Yeah, listen, did you have a phone conversation with a movie producer named Morgan Ross?
Yeah, last week.
Can you tell me about that conversation?
He's got a movie coming out.
"Prince of New York."
Yeah, they wanted to screen it at the White House.
What did you say?
Well, they sent me the print the week before and I looked at it.
And you passed?
Yeah.
Charlie, was the President involved in that decision at all?
No, he lets me choose the movies. I just didn't think he'd like it so I got him "Dial M for murder" instead. Sam?
Okay.
Domo arigato. [hangs up]
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is on the phone. C.J. is gesturing at him at the door.

Dialogues.Line: Well, there'd be fallout from women voters and, I'm pretty sure, the AMA, to say nothing of the First Lady.
Leo?
[covers the handset] I had about nine people on the conference call at several points of longitude. When's your first briefing?
An hour.
Can you show support for the Surgeon General without supporting her policy?
Yeah.
Show me.
Try me.
[in a mock-reporter voice] C.J., did you know that Dr Griffith was going to criticize the administration's drug policy last night?
I don't agree with your categorization of the comments; I think she expressed her opinion about the health effects of certain illegal drugs.
Well, she basically called for legalization of marijuana. Does the President agree with it?

Wrong again, and I will refer you to the Surgeon General's comments. When asked if marijuana should be legalized, she said and I'm quoting, "It's not for me to say." And she's right, and it's important that people understand this the Surgeon General's not a law-maker, she doesn't set drug policy, the President does, and the President is 100% against legalizing drugs including marijuana.
Yeah. [into the phone] Leo, I can take it to the next step. Okay. Okay. [hangs up and stands]
Leo wants me to show her support.
Yeah.
Josh?
Yeah.
While I'm showing her support, what are you showing her?
The door. He puts on his coat and leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Good morning.
C.J.! C.J.!
Hang on. Katie.
Did you know the Surgeon General was going to criticize...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WAITING ROOM OUTSIDE SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh is sitting on a couch, watching C.J.'s briefing on television.

Dialogues.Line: ...the administration's drug policy last night?

Well, first of all, I disagree with your characterization of her comments. She expressed her opinion about the health affects of certain illegal drugs. Jeff. Josh gets off the couch and moves to stand in front of the T.V.
I'm sorry, but didn't she say that...

Actually, what she did say, and I quote, is that there has been no conclusive... C.J.'s briefing continues on the television as the door to the Surgeon General's office opens. A man and woman exit. The Surgeon General appears in the doorway.
Josh?
Dr. Griffith.
You wanna come in?
Yeah. They go inside the SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE.
How've you been feeling?
Well, I've been fine.
They're checking your blood pressure once a week?
Yeah, 130 over 87.
Hmmm. It's a little high. Uh, what about the right leg and arm?
There's a little stiffness.
Yeah. You know, the guys at GW did a fantastic job. It's a beautiful scar.
[surprised] When did you see my scar?
At the hospital.
I don't remember.
You were unconscious. How 'bout your back?
There's some pain.
It's in your head.
[laughs] Along with all manner of things.
Well, you know, Josh, just because the White Supremacists didn't kill you, doesn't mean that that crap you eat isn't gonna.
I eat fine.
You eat like you're still in college.
I was in great shape in college.
You were nineteen in college. You could eat Tupperware and your system would deal with it.
Millicent, what were you thinking about? Dr. Griffith pauses behind her desk, her back to Josh, before turning around to answer him.
I was asked a question, Josh.
I understand, but your answers...
My answers were correct; is anyone challenging me on the facts?
Not yet.

Well, they won't. As a doctor, I have an obligation to tell the truth. Come to think of it, as a person I have that obligation as well. Dr. Griffith sits down in her desk chair and Josh takes a seat in a chair in front of her desk.
The truth is different if you're a GP or a member of the Stanford Faculty Club than if you're the country's chief medical practitioner.
Well, no, I think truth is pretty much truth across the board, never more so than if you're the country's chief medical practitioner.
Did you know that 69% of Americans oppose legalization? Only 23% support it.
The number gets a lot higher than that if you ask people under 30.
Well, that's a shock. Did you know that the number gets even higher than that if you limit the polling sample to Bob Marley and the Whalers?
I mentioned that particular age group because an awful lot of them seem to be in prison.
Is that what this is about?
No!
Because the criminal justice system is nowhere near your jurisdiction...
I wasn't commenting on the criminal justice system...
Millicent!
I wasn't commenting on the criminal justice system! Josh stands up and starts pacing.
[quoting Dr. Griffith] "Yet bizarrely the law categorizes it as a schedule one narcotic?!"
I was commenting on medicine.
I've had three conversations with Leo McGarry in the last 12 hours. The reason I've come here...
Josh, I'm not a politician, but it's not like I haven't lived here for two years.
C.J.'s up there right now giving you our support. I'm sorry, but we need you to resign.
[pause] No.
Dr. Griffith, I say this with all possible respect, but... you serve at the pleasure of the President.
[standing up] And I'll continue to, right up until the moment he fires me. Josh looks at her for a moment before nodding.
Okay. [beat] Thank you, ma'am. He moves towards the door to exit her office, but she stops him.

Josh. See the doctor, get a lollipop. She tosses a lollipop to him from her desk. Josh catches it and looks at her for a moment longer before opening the door. As he exits the office back into the waiting room, C.J.'s briefing is again heard from the TV.
And the fact that the President disagrees with her doesn't mean he's going to fire her. The Surgeon General is an executive appointee and the President stands by his staff.
[under his breath] Excellent. Josh pulls on his coat and leaves as the camera remains on the television.
C.J., shifting gears for a second. There's a full page ad that appears in today's Times...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE, BRIEFING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: ... in fact I've been told it might have appeared in as many as 22 papers this morning. The ad was taken out by the Family Values Leadership Council, and praises, among others, the President, for denouncing a movie that's opening next week, called Prince of New York.
Yes.
You know anything about it?
No, I don't know what the hell's going on there.
C.J., the President didn't denounce it?

Not unless he did it in the shower. But he hasn't denounced it to me and he certainly hasn't to the public. [The reporters chuckle.] That's all. See you this afternoon. The reporters continue to call C.J.'s name as she leaves the podium. Carol approaches and hands her some papers.
Sam's here.
Thank you.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam is waiting for C.J. As they talk, they move through the hallways.

Dialogues.Line: Good job.
Please tell me what's going on with this movie.
It's called Prince of New York.
Right.
There's been some controversy about it.
Sex and violence?
And religious imagery. Family and religious groups are organizing boycotts.
Right.
The studio phone banks Charlie because they want a screening, and Charlie passes.
Why?
Because he did. The producer goes on Imus and says Bartlet's a coward who's siding with Puritanical censors and that Hollywood should know he's no friend of the First Amendment.
And then the Family Values Leadership Council took out an ad congratulating us for that?
Yeah.
Seriously, I quit.
Here's the thing.
Wait.
We've got these people...
Wait.
We've got the industry people...
Prince of New York is Morgan Ross's movie.
Yes. But we've got these people...
Morgan Ross went on Imus?
Well, he did it by phone...
Morgan Ross called the President a coward?
He didn't call him a coward as much as...
What?
He called him cowardly. Which is different.
How's it different?
It's not, but still...
I'm gonna crush him.
This guy's trying to get a little free media by screwing with us!
Look.
I'm the enforcer, Sam. I'm gonna crush him, I'm gonna make him cry, and then I'm gonna tell his momma about it! C.J. pours herself some coffee with a grim smile on her face.
You're not going to make him cry.
You wanna watch me make him cry? [chuckles evilly] They reach C.J.'S OFFICE.
I believe that you can make him cry, I'm saying you're not going to do it.
Sam.
I'm trying to tell you we're meeting with these people tomorrow. I'll straighten things out with Morgan Ross. Would you just keep telling the press that you don't know anything?
[sighs] That shouldn't be a problem.
C.J.?
[to C.J.] Thank you. [leaves]
Danny Concannon's on the phone, and I think you should take it.
Why?
He wants the President's reaction to a comment that was made about the situation with Millicent Griffith.
Who made the comment?
That's the thing.
[makes a "hurry up" motion with her hands] Carol.
It was Eleanor.
Eleanor who?
It was Eleanor Bartlet. C.J. stares at her for a second before picking up the phone.
[into phone] Hey, it's C.J.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is in a meeting with several people about the Blue Ribbon Committee the President proposed in the State of the Union.

Dialogues.Line: Toby, it's not that we don't understand your position. But I'm telling you, the commission will not be credible with our people unless there's someone on it who's a friend of labor.
And a friend of seniors.
The President's a friend of labour, a friend of seniors, a friend of small animals...
Toby!
We're running out of time, Lenny. We announced this thing at the State of the Union; we've got to get it going.
The State of the Union's your problem. Nobody brought us in.
Yes.
And I for one am not sure I see a need for emergency-like speed.
Really.
If current economic conditions continue...

Forever? You mean if we never have another recession ever again? Then the fund can withstand all of 30 years before going bankrupt. Unfortunately, the actuarial tables say I won't be dead yet. [sighs] Guys... Gillette's a tough needle to thread. I want to know that we have your trust, that whoever we do get will look out for your interests and that you therefore will support the Commission. Beat, as no one responds, and Toby sighs again.
[cont] Can I assume from your total silence and blank faces that you're all with me?
Maybe if we, uh, talk some more.
[sarcastically] Oh, could we?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Josh.
Listen...
She didn't?
No. Leo's gonna need to talk to her. In the meantime, you should start to walk back some of what you said in the press room, all right?
There's something stickier than the support I gave her in the press room.
What?
Danny Concannon's quoting Eleanor Bartlet. She said, "My father won't fire the Surgeon General. He would never do that."
Eleanor?
Yeah.
You mean Zoey.
No. It was Eleanor. Josh looks both surprised and exasperated, and lets out a big sigh.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Charlie are exiting Air Force One, discussing the situation in Japan. Leo, a limo, numerous police cars, and a crowd of reporters are there to greet them.

Dialogues.Line: They're trying to export their way out of their own economic problems.
Yes, sir.
And by dumping low priced steel on the U.S., you know what they're asking for?
A protectionist response.

They're begging for a protectionist response. Steel and mining employ a hundred and seventy thousand workers. They're not going to sit around while discount steel comes flying into... how you doing? [waves to someone calling "Welcome back, sir!"] They're going to want retaliatory tariffs, and you know what that means?
A return to Smoot-Hawley and the Great Depression.
A return to Smoot-Hawley and the Great Depression.
Well, you should go to Japan and tell them that, sir. They start to head towards the reporters, but Leo comes up behind them.
Charlie!
[stopping Bartlet] Sir.
Leo, I'm walking over to the press and telling them that retaliatory tariffs are gonna cost American taxpayers eight hundred thousand dollars for every job saved.
We're not taking questions. Let's get in the car. They move towards the limo, as reporters faintly call after them.
What's going on?
Eleanor made a comment on the record and you can't answer questions right now.
Eleanor?
Yeah.
You mean Zoey.
It was Eleanor.
When did this happen?
About six hours ago.
Why didn't you tell me six hours ago?
[quietly] Because I didn't want you crash-landing the plane. Let's get in the car. Nancy holds open the limo door for Bartlet.
Welcome back, Mr. President. Bartlet doesn't answer, just gives a wave to the reporters and climbs into the car. The door is closed behind him.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Josh, is there anything to suggest that there are a significant number of people who are inclined to smoke pot but don't because it's against the law?
No.

Then why do you think if it were decriminalized there would be a sudden stampede of people showing up to work stoned, dragging down the economy and clearing supermarket aisles of Pringles and Twinkies?
That's not a reason to make it legal.
In a free society, you don't need a reason to make something legal... you need a reason to make something illegal.
Donna, parents are keeping kids away from drugs with a whip and a chair. It doesn't help them out if we...
[answers phone] Yes?
No, that's Okay, it's just me, talking...
[hangs up] President's back.
Does he want to see me?
Yeah? Josh exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Welcome back, Mr. President.
[angry] Thank you. I've had it, C.J. I've absolutely had it!
Sir...
What the hell is Danny Concannon doing calling to my kid?
Mr. President...
He knows better than that! They all know better than that! But Danny...
Sir, he didn't...
C.J., you're going to suspend his credentials for six months, and I don't give a damn. His paper wants to cover the President, they can send someone else.
Mr. President, Danny didn't call her.
I was told it was Danny.
Yes, sir. She called him.
[pause] She called him? Bartlet sits down at his desk. Josh enters.
Good evening, welcome back Mr. President.
The Allman Brothers, Josh?
How was the flight, sir?
Tokyo is willing to show economic restraint, in exchange for a good fielding shortstop and a left-handed reliever... Who's against us so far?
The Judiciary Committee, Government Reform and Oversight, Appropriations...
Appropriations?
They control the Surgeon General's budget.
Who's coming to her defense?
The Cannabis Society, The Cannabis Coalition, E Cannabis Unum, The American Hemp League, and Friends of Mary Jane.
Sir?
Yeah?
Sam's waiting to see you.
Yes, I understand I've been congratulated for denouncing a movie I've never heard of.
Yes sir.
I've got to hand it to you guys you've pulled off a political first. You've managed to win me the support of the Christian Right and the Cheech and Chong Fan Club in the same day.
Leo's seeing her tomorrow.
Anything else?
No sir.
Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. C.J. and Josh exit.
Charlie? Would you arrange for my middle daughter to come see me at her earliest possible convenience?
Yes sir.
Ah, screw her convenience. Get her ass down here. Charlie exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY
CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam is at his desk typing. Toby bounces a ball off his window. Sam comes to TOBY'S OFFICE.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah?
What's this note?
That note?
Yeah.
It says that we should stand by the Surgeon General.
Actually, it says that we should stand by the Sturgeon General.
Does it?
Yeah.
I meant Surgeon General.
Well, I think we should stand by her too. I just wanted to make sure we were agreed that smoked white fish was pretty much on its own.
Yeah.
Toby?
She's here?
In the lobby. We follow Toby and Sam out of Toby's office.
You're with the ratings people?
Soon. What's the food for?
Today's attempt at ensuring out future.
What's your plan?
The first thing I have to do is be nice to a liberal Democratic Congresswoman.
Will that be hard?
Well, it was when I was married to her. They reach Congresswoman Andrea Wyatt in the LOBBY.
Good to see you. Thanks for coming. You look fantastic.
Thank you. How've you been, Sam?
Sam's great.
Fit as a fiddle, Andy. Although, to tell you the truth, I found...
Nobody cares.
Yeah. [exits]
Hi. Andy kisses Toby on the cheek.
How're you doing?
Congresswoman Wyatt.
Yes, indeed. Toby and Andy walk back to his office.
You're growing into that title very nicely.
This is going someplace hysterical.
Heh. Yeah. Labor wants Gillette on the Commission.
Yes.
So does the AARP.
Yes.
It's very important to them.
Yes.
Do you know why?
'Cause they've been very suspicious of the Commission since you announced it, and want one of their people protecting their interests? They reach TOBY'S OFFICE.
We're one of their people.
Have you had an easy time convincing them of that since you announced the Commission?
No. But I bring you here, and we sit, and we have coffee, and we have Danish, in the hope that calmer and, dare I say, prettier heads prevail.
Oh, I miss patronizing, sexist Toby.
I was referring to myself.
You don't want to ask Gillette?
Nope.
'Cause you think he might say no.
Right. This is really important, Andy. Can you help us?
No.
Toby?
Close the door. Andy picks up a Danish.
Put the Danish down.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Mrs. Landingham and Charlie are shuttling binders.

Dialogues.Line: "Dial M."
Yeah.
A fine film.
I know it well.
Ray Milland, Grace Kelly, Robert Cummings...
He likes the part where the guy looks for the key.
And what was the other one about?
"Prince of New York?"
Yeah.

[reading off a sheet of paper] It's an updated version of Dostoyevsky's "The Idiot" which tells the story of a Christ-like epileptic young man who embodies goodness, but encounters sex, crime, and family dysfunction.
Hard to imagine why you didn't think the President would enjoy that, Charlie.
Well he would have especially enjoyed the scene where the Prince Myshkin character has a seizure while engaging in an erotic fantasy in a Long Island church.
Charlie, please don't say the word "erotic" in the Oval Office.
I'd be perfectly happy never to say any of those words anywhere ever again.
John Williams as Chief Inspector Hubbard.
Not to mention...
Excuse me. Mrs. Landingham and Charlie stop, turn and see ELEANOR BARTLET.
Ellie!
I was told my father wanted to see me? Mrs. Landingham nods and exits.
Let me ask you this...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: LEO'S OUTER OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Margaret and Dr. Griffith are talking.

Dialogues.Line: Red meat has been found to cause cancer in white rats. Maraschino cherries have been found to cause cancer in white rats. Cellular phones have been found to cause cancer in white rats. Has anyone examined the possibility that cancer might be hereditary in white rats?
Let me tell you something, I'm not 100% sure we've ruled that out. Leo walks through to his office.
Dr. Griffith.
[to Margaret] I'm on. Dr. Griffith enters LEO'S OFFICE. Leo closes the door.

Congratulations, Millie. You're now the pamphlet girl for every right fundraising cause. That interview's got to be worth at least twenty, thirty million bucks in contributions from people who think you're going to distribute dime bags of Hawaiian sens at junior high schools along with condoms and fornication manuals.
Can I say, I was never given a fornication manual, so...
You think this is funny?
I think that we're spending a billion dollars a year keeping more than forty thousand people locked up.
That's not your...
I know that's not my jurisdiction, which is why I never commented on decriminalization.
Six different committee chairs... three in the House, three in the Senate... are all talking about hearings.
What are they going to find?

They don't need to find anything. They just need to say your name and "drugs" as many times as possible on television. I don't think you said anything wrong. Nobody with a brain thinks you did anything wrong. And I'd like to do the right thing all the time, but I can't. I can't let us get bogged down in this crap. Government will stop, this will be what we do for two months, and there are more important things than that. I'll take the heat from the First Lady, but I want your resignation by eight o'clock tonight or the President's gonna fire you. I've got a meeting. [exits]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Charlie is at his desk. Ellie sits nervously across from him.

Dialogues.Line: Zoey said you were thinking about oncology.
Excuse me?
Zoey said you were thinking about oncology.
Yeah, or neurology.
He's just tied up in this meeting down the hall.
I'm fine.
They said he should be back any minute.
I'm... good. Yeah.
You like medical school?
I do. I like my professors. I have a pathophysiology professor who teaches clinical skills by...
Eagle's moving. We hear Bartlet storming up the hall.
...in consumer costs per job saved. Retaliatory tariffs on steel imports are a disaster. Anyone wants to check my math, they're more than welcome to. Bartlet enters with advisors.
Anybody wants to shove the Golden Gate Bridge up Japan's ass, they're more than welcome to do that too.
Mr. President? [motions to Ellie]
Oh... [turns to advisors] Thank you. The advisors exit.
Ellie, thanks for coming.
Hi, dad. Bartlet kisses her on the cheek.
Come on in.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Did you get down here Okay?
Yeah.
Did you take an airplane?
An airplane? No.
A helicopter?
No, the agents drove me.
That's because you go to school at Johns Hopkins, right?
Dad...

And Johns Hopkins is in Baltimore. I'm asking 'cause Baltimore is a 45-minute car ride from Washington, D.C. and we hardly see you anymore. So, I thought either you transfered to a different medical school, they moved Johns Hopkins, or they moved Baltimore. Are any of those things true?
No.
Okay. And this is accurate, right? This quote "My father won't fire the Surgeon General. He would never do that."
Yes.
Elanor, when you put your head down, your hair falls in your face, and I can't see your face, and I can't hear what you're saying. Now look at me, and talk to me.
Yes, the quote is accurate.
What the hell are you doing talking to a reporter?

[getting angry] I have set up monumental, unprecedented, unbreakable rules about my children and the press. I have gotten White House reporters transferred to Yemen for approaching Zoey and Elizabeth. It is the law! [walks away to calm down] Well, I'm sure before you gave the quote you cleared it with the Communications Office. I'm sure you went over the exact wording with C.J. Cregg and coordinated with White House strategy so that the timing was right in the news cycle. I'm certain you consulted the appropriate party leadership because you're a pretty knowledgeable operative having spent so much time with me. Ellie?
Dad...
What?
She was... she was...
WHAT?
She was doing...
Pick your head up!

She was doing exactly what she is supposed to do! She... I'm sorry. She was asked a question, and she said what she knew to be true. And when you start firing doctors for that, you've crossed the line somewhere.
There is politics involved in this, Ellie. And you knew it would make me unhappy and that's why you did it and that's cheap.
I didn't do it to make you unhappy, Dad.
Well, you sure didn't do it to make me happy!
I don't know HOW to make you happy, Dad! For that, you've got to talk to Zoey or Liz. Silence ensues.
Okay, let's drop it. Bartlet walks back behind his desk.
Mom gets back first thing in the morning and we're running a movie tonight if you want to stay over.
I can stay over if you want me to.
Yeah, thanks. Bartlet shuffles some papers. Ellie takes her purse, turns to leave, then looks around nervously.
I go out...?
That door over there. [points] Ellie exits. Charlie enters from another door.
Mr. President?
Yeah.
The Labor Secretary.
Send him in. [beat] Charlie... Give me just a minute, would you?
Yes sir. Charlie exits. Bartlet turns and looks out the window, thinking.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Andy and Toby are yelling almost at the top of their voices.

Dialogues.Line: Hang on.
Look.
Hang on!
No, I will not hang on.

Yes, you will, you will summon your strength and you will listen to me for a moment. [beat] You guys made a hairpin turn at the State of the Union and you did it without consulting a whole lot of members of the liberal wing of the Democratic Party.
Sad to say, Andrea, there aren't a whole lot of members of the liberal wing of the Democratic Party. [shoots the ball off the wall]
So you'll forgive some people if they're concerned that one of the options you're going to explore is raising the retirement age.
Hey, Andy, people are living decades longer than anyone at this rate in 1935!
So you are considering it!
We want to consider everything, but we can't consider anything, unless...
Why does this have to happen in secret?

Because it's the only way it's gonna happen! Because you can't solve Social Security and ask people to run for election at the same time! So why not give politicians some cloud cover and let them be lawmakers for a while? Fifteen people in a room with the door closed; seven democrats, seven republicans, and the President of the United States, who will not have a vote, and they walk out of that room, and with one voice they make a recommendation to Congress and the American people! And nobody knows who was where! [sighs] The only way this is going to happen is in secret. And they only way it's going to happen is if all the sides are confident in their representation. Otherwise it's dead, and so I need Seth Gillette on the commission, but I can't ask him, 'cause if he says no, there'll be no commission! [beat] Anyway... I appreciate you coming down and talking to me. [heads to open the door for her] They both walk out of his office.
I like when you ask for my help, Toby.
Listen, I read in the paper that I'm on the benefit committee for the Child Leukemia Foundation.
[putting her coat on, smiling] Yeah, I saw that, too.
Why do you suppose the paper wrote that?
I don't know. I guess they must have gotten it from that press release of something.
I guess they must have. You don't think it'd be a better idea if you asked me first?
I really didn't.
Interesting.
I find that when I skip over the first step and move right to the second step, it becomes a lot harder for people to say no. Toby stops suddenly.
Listen, you'll have fun, you'll look nice in your tuxedo, you don't have to stay, you don't have... [turns to him] Toby?
Skip over the first step and move right to the second.
[walking from behind Andy] Toby... Hey, Andy!
Hey, C.J..
[to Toby] Toby, when you have a minute, can you stop by the office, I need... Toby is staring past her at Andy.
What?
C.J., tomorrow morning I want you to announce that Seth Gillette's joined the Blue Ribbon Commission on Social Security.
Toby...

Make sure the press knows the Senator put the Democratic Party above personal differences, and that he put people above all. Make sure they know that he's a patriot, and when the President asked him to serve, Senator Gillette answered the call.
Did he?
Yeah. I just saw it at your press briefing tomorrow morning.
Okay, but this is really the last thing I'm doing before I quit.
[as she walks away] Okay. Andy smiles approvingly.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Ed is meeting with Hollywood representatives.

Dialogues.Line: It's like checking the sugar and fat content on a box of cereal.
We bend over backwards to help parents make choices.
We put V-chips in TVs, warning labels on records, TV shows, film ads... Sam walks in and stands by the door. He whispers to the secretary and she comes to Morgan Ross and talks to him quietly.
And when we do, we suffer, because our products become demonized and marginalized, and every ten years the Government asks for something more. Ross steps outside.
The only reason we have to come to you every ten years is that the situation isn't getting any better.
When's the government going to ask the NFL and the National Hockey League to put warning labels on their games?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Can I talk to you?
Sure.
Come on. Sam starts walking to his office. Ross follows.
He's wrong in there, by the way, the situation hasn't stayed the same, there's been a 28% drop in juvenile crime in the last five years, 10% drop in the overall crime rate.
I don't care.
Why?
'Cause, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the AMA and the American Psychological association all say that watching violence on TV is bad for kids and we're gonna listen to the experts.
I'll remember that tomorrow morning when I read in the paper the Surgeon General's been fired.
Remember it whenever you'd like.
What is he seeing tonight?
"Dial M for murder." Ross Good. Hitchcock never used sex or violence in his films.
Yeah. Morgan, the President's never seen your movie, he's never heard of your movie, he has no particular objection to your movie, and you know it.
The Family Values Leadership Council seems to see it differently.
Gloriosky, Morgan, the Family Values Leadership Council distorted the truth. Stop the presses.
Well, thanks to that ad, I've got exhibitors in Mississippi, Oklahoma and Alabama, pulling the film!
I've read the press synopsis of the film, and if the exhibitors put you on every screen of every multiplex in every mall you still wouldn't do any business in Mississippi, Oklahoma or Alabama.
You're an industry expert now.
No, but you are. Which explains a lot to me about Hollywood. And you know the ad was going to get you more business than you lost and that's why you went on Imus and said what you did.
I'm here for a Sam Seaborn scolding?

Yeah. Because it makes me crazy, Morgan, this is exactly the kind of thing that should be celebrated by First Amendment advocates. Charlie was offered a choice and he made one. Why aren't you standing up, saying, "See, it works! You don't need to ban movies like "Prince of New York", you just have to choose not to watch them!" And Morgan you ever call the President a coward again for your own PR purposes, it's not going to be C.J. Cregg you gotta deal with, it's going to be me. You understand what I'm saying, right?
[very slowly] Yes.
Now why don't you go back to your meeting and show me how much you want to make it up to us. Sam sits down at his desk, Ross leaves. Toby walks by and throws Sam his rubber ball.
Good job. Sam smiles.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. MOVIE THEATER IN THE WHITE HOUSE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: The phone rings on the screen, the senior staff, Bartlet, and Ellie are watching.

Dialogues.Line: [in the back, to Donna] This isn't good.
What?
The President's not talking.
There's a movie on.
He usually talks during the movie. Bartlet stands up and leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The Surgeon General is waiting, dressed in formal attire. Bartlet walks in.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening.
Good evening, Mr. President.
I'm sorry about this.
Yes, sir.
Is that your resignation?
[holds up the paper] Yes, sir.
Thank you.
On thinking about it, I felt your firing me would send a dangerous signal to whomever had my job next.
Did you not think that playing down the dangers of drug use sent a dangerous signal as well?

I do not believe that is what I did, sir. I was asked, by and large, if marijuana holds the same addictive properties as heroin or LSD; it does not. I was asked if marijuana poses a greater health risk than nicotine and alcohol, and in my opinion, it does not. And I believe if you look at the transcript...
Millie, did you put her up to it?
Sir?
"My father won't fire the Surgeon General, he would never do that." You didn't put her up to it?
No, sir.
You didn't pick up the phone after Josh came to see you and say, "Ellie, it's your godmother, let's stick it to your old man, and paint him into a corner?"
No, sir.
Why haven't I ever been able to get her to like me? I'm asking you.
Sir, I'm not sure it's appropriate...
I'm asking you.
Well, I think you're wrong.
I'm not.
She worships you, Mr. President...
She's mad at me. Dr. Griffith Well, you're mad at her.
Yes, I am!
Sir...
I was running for President, where the hell was she?
She was with us.
Not like Zoey and Liz.
Sir...
She's always belonged to Abbey.
You frightened her.
No, I didn't!
Sir...
How did I frighten her?
Jed, look where you're standing!
I was elected two years ago, she's 24 years old!
You've been the king of whatever room you walked into her entire life.
It never seemed to intimidate Zoey or Liz.
Well, kids are different, they're not the same! You would be amazed, you'd be stunned at how soon they understand they're not their father's favorite.
That's not true.
Sir...
That's not true.
Mr. President...

No, no, no. I will bear with the nonsense of the Christian right and the Hollywood left and the AFL-CIO and the AARP and the Canubus society and Japan, but I will not stand and allow someone to tell me that I love one of my children less than the others. [walks to the glass door] She's frightened of me?
She ain't the only one.

I wanted to be so mad at her. I heard the news and my first thought was.. My god, "King Lear" is a good play. [sighs] "My father won't fire the Surgeon General, he would never do that." I wanted to be so mad at her. But the truth is, it's the nicest thing she's ever said about me.
Well, good night, sir.
Good night. Dr. Griffith walks to the door.
Hey, doc!
Sir?
I don't accept it.
I'm sorry, sir?
I don't accept your resignation.
Sir, I appreciate that, but Leo's right. This shouldn't stop you from doing the bigger things.
These are the bigger things. I don't accept your resignation. [hands her the paper] You work for me. You go when I tell you to.
You're an excellent role model, Mr. President.
[walking out the glass door, turns] Yes, I know.
So you're back.
[from outside] Yes, indeed.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MOVIE THEATER - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Tell
, when she gives Millie our support on Monday, she can mean it.
[stands up] You know, it's going to seem to some people like you did it 'case your daughter asked you to.

You know, Josh, I think if you ever have a daughter, you're going to discover there are worse reasons in the world to do something. Sit down, we're coming to the good part. He walks past him to sit near Ellie.
What is he doing?
He's wondering why that key doesn't fit. He's going round to the main entrance. He stopped again...
[to Ellie] How you doing?
Hmmm?
I said, how you doing?
Fine.
You know, we're coming up to the good part.
Dad, people are trying to watch the movie.
You want to bet me your tuition no one in this room is going to shush me? Ellie shakes her head.
I hear you're thinking about ophthalmology.
[not looking at him] Oncology.
[not looking at her either] Why would you want to study people's feet?
That's podiatry.
That's children's medicine.
Pediatrics.
I thought it was obstetrics.
That's pregnant women.
And what's the study of feet?
[looking at him] Dad, you're not going to make me laugh.
Hmmm? [beat, while he looks at her gently] The only thing you ever had to do to make me happy was come home at the end of the day. Ellie looks like she's about to cry.
So, endocrinology would be what? Disorders of the gallbladder?
[chokes the word] Thyroid.
I'm pretty sure you're wrong about that, I think endocrinology is your sub-specialty of internal medicine, devoted to the digestive system.
That would be gastroenterology.
Are you sure it's not nephrology, immunology, cardiology, or dermatology?
[smiling] Would you stop it? I'm trying to watch the movie.
Okay. Here comes the good part. They sit there, watching the movie, close to each other.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
